In addition to being responsible for the characteristic cutoff at Q * 27 GeV explained in the previous subsection, the cuts on the individual transverse momenta p7 also introduce a dependence of the invariant mass distribution on the shape of the Qr spectrum of the yy pairs. Because of this correlation between the Q and Qr distributions, the discontinuities in do/dQr as Qr — 0, when computed at finite order, make finite-order predictions for do/dQ somewhat unstable. The finite-order expectation for the transverse momentum distribution do/dQr (i.e., the integral of P(Q, Qr, y,Q.) over Q, y, and Q,, or P for brevity) is shown as a dashed curve in Fig. B(a). It exhibits an integrable singularity in the small-Qr limit. Terms with inverse power and logarithmic dependence on Qr, associated with initial-state radiation as Qr — 0, are extracted from P and form the asymptotic contribution, denoted as A (dotted curve). In the figure, both P and A are truncated at a small value of Qr, that is, not drawn all the way to Qr = 0. The curves for P and A are close at small values of Qr, signaling that the initial-state logarithmic singularities dominate the NLO dist
